title: Aging & AIDS

content: When I was diagnosed with AIDS more than 20 years ago, I never thought I’d see old age. Now 52, I’m middle aged and growing older. There are issues at the intersection of AIDS and aging to take into account – like comorbidities, mental health issues, isolation, medication interactions, and other challenges.
Did you know the largest demographic living with HIV is the 50+ community?

Today’s medications make it possible to live a long and healthy life with HIV/AIDS. But increased life expectancy presents a new set of challenges. Living with this condition already has challenges, and aging adds to them.
Let’s take a look at those.

Comorbidities are a new concern for me. Older adults with HIV/AIDS are more likely to develop conditions like cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, and certain cancers. This can be due to a combination of factors, including the HIV virus itself, long-term effects of ART (antiretroviral therapy), and lifestyle factors. They complicate the aging process.

content: Long-term use of ART can have positive and negative effects on aging.

On one hand, modern medicine helps control the virus and prevent HIV-related complications. On the other hand, some medications may have side effects or may interact with other medications used to manage age-related conditions. So it’s important to communicate with your doctors about any medications you take.
Older adults with HIV may face unique mental health challenges.
You may experience social isolation, depression, anxiety, or cognitive decline. After 23 years of living with this condition. I’ve experienced these. They’re common.

Some long-term survivors of HIV experience a phenomenon called survivor’s guilt. This comes from losing friends to AIDS while you live with their memories. These mental health struggles can bring down your health overall. It’s important to address them and seek appropriate support.

Comprehensive care is important as we age. To address the specific needs of older adults with HIV, a multidisciplinary approach is crucial. This includes regular medical checkups, screenings for age-related conditions, mental health support, and social services. It’s important to keep your appointments and follow treatment guidelines as prescribed by your doctors.

content: Healthy aging is possible by adopting a healthy lifestyle, but this isn’t easy for older adults with HIV. It includes regular exercise, a balanced diet, managing stress, avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol, and getting enough sleep. This is self-care.
It's important to know that everyone's experience with HIV/AIDS and aging is unique.

Regular communication with your health care providers and sticking to your treatment plan are key to maintaining your overall health and well-being. Thanks to modern medicine, the population of those aging with HIV is growing, and it’s expected to continue growing.

Aging with HIV is something I wasn’t expecting. It's a blessing.  I continue to learn, as I evolve and grow older, how to coexist with this virus and other conditions, along with an ever-expanding list of medications.
But I can face my future with confidence and without fear. I got this. And so do you.
Join others living with HIV, recently diagnosed, or supporting someone who has it by joining our HIV Facebook Support Group .
